Question: Personal data is any information relating to an identified or identifiable person (name, location, online identifier, etc.--see GDPR Article 4). Does your organization collect user's personal data?

Data processing is considered any operation on data (i.e. collection, recording, storage, retrieval, etc.--see GDPR Article 4), automated or not, regardless of who/what originally obtainted the data from the user (i.e. a company you contract with collected it and transmitted it to you for some purpose). Do you process personal data? (*If you collect, you process!)
Did the personal data that you collect/process originate from an individual in the European Union?
In order to process data, you must have a lawful basis for processing. Do you have a lawful basis for your data processing?
Descriptions: As per GDPR Article 6, a lawful basis is any one of the following: the user that the data came from gave consent; the data processing is necessary as part of your role in a contract with the user that supplied the data; the processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation; the processing is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the user or another person; the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the data controller; the processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the data controller or by a third party.

Question: When processing personal data, do you have a specified purpose for doing so?
Descriptions: E.g. A specified purpose would be comparable to collecting a user's address to ship them a product and that is exactly what the data is being used for.

Question: Is your "specified purpose" one that would be considered legitimate in relation to your service/product?
Descriptions: E.g. if you're selling t-shirt online, requesting a user's address to send them their t-shirt would be considered a legitimate relation.

Question: Was the user that the data was collected from informed that you collected their data?
Was the user that the data was collected from informed of the specific purpose their data was collected for?
Did the user that the data was collected from give consent for the data to be processed?
Descriptions: Pursuant to Articles 4, 6, 7, and 8, consent can be defined as any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.

Question: Is your data processing only for the reason explicitly stated to the user that the user consented to?
Do you have a mechanism to ensure the accuracy/currentness of the personal data that is processed?
Do you have a mechanism to ensure the erasure of personal data found to be inaccurate?
Do you have a retention period for the personal data that you process?
Is the data kept in a form that permits identification of the user from which the data came?
Is your retention period no longer than is necessary for the purpose of your data processing?
Do you ensure appropriate technological and organizational safeguards and security for processed personal data?
If the data you process is based on a user's consent, can you easily show that the user supplied consent?
When the user is asked for consent, is the request clear for the purpose it is being asked for and disinguishable from any other purpose?
Was the request for the user's consent given in an intelligible and easily accessible form using clear and plain language?
Would you consider the user's consent informed and unambiguous?
Does the user have the ability to withdraw consent?
Is the mechanism to withdraw consent just as easy as the mechanism to give consent?
Was the user informed that the user has the right to withdraw consent?
Do you process data from children less than 16 years of age?
For data processed for children less than 16 years of age, were reasonable efforts taken to ensure relevant parental consent was given?
Does your company have a privacy statement (often referred to as a privacy policy or privacy notice) made available to users?
Is your privacy notice easily accessible for users and free of charge?
Is your privacy notice concise, fully transparent, and written in clear and plain language?
